matched.actualTitle: Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI) in Registration Step 3
matched.matchReason: Both findings identify the same SSTI vulnerability where unsanitized user input from session data (request.session['name']) is directly interpolated into a Django template string without sanitization. The vulnerability is in the same file and line range (expected: lines 60-63, actual: line 63). Both describe the same attack vector: user input being evaluated as template code, allowing access to sensitive context variables like the flag.

extra.title: Unauthenticated Access to Web Terminal - Authentication Bypass
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate critical vulnerability in a web terminal service that was not in the expected findings list. The terminal is completely unprotected and accessible without authentication, allowing arbitrary command execution.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers - Information Disclosure and Clickjacking Risk
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate vulnerability affecting HTTP security posture. Missing critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, CSP, etc.) is a valid finding not in the expected list.

extra.title: HTTP/0.9 Protocol Smuggling via SSH Banner Injection
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate protocol smuggling vulnerability where HTTP/0.9 requests can trigger SSH protocol switching. This is a valid security finding not in the expected list.

extra.title: No Rate Limiting or Connection Limits on WebSocket Endpoint - Denial of Service
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate Denial of Service vulnerability enabling unlimited concurrent connections and high-rate command execution. A valid security issue not in the expected findings.

extra.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) via WebSocket - No Token Validation
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate CSRF vulnerability where WebSocket connections lack CSRF token validation and origin checking. A valid security finding not in the expected list.

extra.title: All HTTP Endpoints Return 404 - No API Surface Exposed
extra.assessment: New discovery - While this could be a configuration issue, it represents a legitimate availability concern where all endpoints return 404. This indicates either complete misconfiguration or service failure, a valid operational security finding.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Unrestricted System Information Access via Terminal
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a valid security finding showing information disclosure through unfiltered terminal output. Sensitive system information (users, processes, environment variables, network config) can be accessed without restriction.

extra.title: Insecure WebSocket Message Handling - Unvalidated Input and Race Conditions
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate vulnerability in the terminal's WebSocket message handling code. Duplicate handlers, unvalidated input processing, and lack of message length validation represent valid security issues.

extra.title: Weak SSH Cryptography Configuration - Legacy Algorithms Enabled
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a valid cryptographic security finding identifying legacy algorithms (ssh-rsa) that should be disabled. Compliance and cryptographic best practices violation.

extra.title: Inline Scripts Without Content Security Policy - Code Injection Risk
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate XSS vulnerability where inline scripts lack CSP protection and external resources lack SRI integrity hashes. Valid security finding for code injection prevention.

extra.title: SSH Implementation Information Disclosure via Banner
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a valid but low-impact finding identifying SSH implementation details (SSH-2.0-Go) that aids reconnaissance. While informational, it represents unnecessary information disclosure.
